About Me

Hello! Thank you for taking the time to visit my website. My name is Saroosh Ashraf and I am a third-year mechanical engineering student. As I progress through my years in university, I have taken a particular liking to mechanical design and infrastructure and gained a particular passionate talent in CAD modelling. I am extremely eager to learn and broaden my knowledge in the field, constantly participating in competitions and extra curricular activities. Currently, I am taking an extra curricular course offered by the MMRI, McMaster Manufacturing Research Institute.

In my spare time, I enjoy taking on personal projects such as tinkering with 3D printing, as well as assembling Personal Computers for my friends and family. I enjoy playing the guitar as a hobby, and have a zest for travelling with my friends and family.

I hope you enjoy viewing my personal projects and experiences that I have partaken in over the years!

Projects

This project was particularly exciting because it introduced me to the workings of gear trains and 3D printing.

Using Autodesk Inventor to design gears and housing brackets, me and my group were able to mount gears to 3D printed components and use a rotating crank to make two “fingers” rotate and touch.

To kick up the complexity, in my 2nd year I was tasked with designing a gripper component with CAD but this time the challenge was to communicate my design further rather than just simply 3D printing it.

To communicate my design, I designed professional engineering schematics, complete with collapsed view, bill of materials, and exploded view to truly detail the construction of the gripper components.

With the mastery of inventor, this project was designed to be particularly challenging because it combined an electrical aspect.

Using CAD to design the housing for a motor and moving arms, me and my group were able to have the motors output their torque to the claw arms and create a robot that was not only able to move, but go over obstacles. This project felt particularly fulfilling to me because it allowed me to design something that actually accomplished a task of some sort.

As I mentioned before, I enjoy taking part in engineering competitions to test my abilities and apply my knowledge to fun tasks.

At the 2020 designathon held at McMaster, I was able to create a CAD model of a “living pod”, constrained with various quantities, such as max volume, and max material cost. The design was praised by judges as being very space efficient.
